metadata.title: Role of the atmospheric pollution in the Covid-19 outbreak risk in Italy 1

abstract.text: Background: After the initial outbreak in China, the diffusion in Italy of SARS-CoV-2 is exhibiting a 7 clear regional trend with Northern areas being the most affected in terms of both frequency and 8 severity of cases. Among multiple factors possibly involved in such geographical differences, a role 9 has been hypothesized for atmospheric pollution.

body_text.text: contamination may represent a favourable context for the spread of the virus. Pro-inflammatory 23 responses and high incidence of respiratory and cardiac affections are well known, while the 24 capability of this coronavirus to bind particulate matters remains to be established. Atmospheric 25 and environmental pollution should be considered as part of an integrated approach for sustainable 26 development, human health protection and prevention of epidemic spreads. 27 Keywords: COVID-19; Atmospheric Pollution; Pandemic risk; Italy 28 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 25, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04. 23.20076455 doi: medRxiv preprint -3 - 29 In December 2019, several pneumonia cases were suddenly observed in the metropolitan city 30 of Wuhan (China), as the result of infection to a novel coronavirus (Li et al., 2020 ; Wu et al., 2020; 31 Xu et al., 2020) . This virus was termed SARS-CoV-2 for its similarity with that responsible of the 32 global epidemic Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) occurred between 2002 and 2003 (Xu 33 et al., 2020). Patients affected by SARS-CoV-2 infection often experienced serious complications, 34 including organ failure, septic shock, pulmonary oedema, severe pneumonia and acute respiratory 35 stress syndrome which in several cases were fatal Sohrabi et al., 2020 The drastic containment measures adopted by Chinese government did not prevent the 42 diffusion of SARS-CoV-2, which in a few weeks has spread globally. Italy was the first country in 43 Europe to be affected by the epidemic COVID-19, with an outbreak even larger than that originally The percentage of European population exposed to levels higher than the regulatory limits 82 is about 7-8% for NO2, 6-8% for PM2.5, 13-19% for PM10 and 12-29% for O3 (EEA, 2019). Premature 83 deaths due to acute respiratory diseases from such pollutants are estimated to be over to two . FIGREF0.text: 44observed in China (Fanelli and Piazza, 2020;Remuzzi and Remuzzi, 2020). Other European countries45    and United States rapidly registered an exponential growth of clinical cases, leading to restrictions46    and a global lockdown with evident social and economic repercussions(Cohen and Kupferschmidt,   47    2020; ECDC, 2020). The WHO has recently declared the pandemic state of COVID-19 with over 1.3 48 million of cases reported and over 74.000 victims worldwide (Cucinotta and Vanelli, 2020; epidemic trend in Italy immediately showed strong regional differences in the 51 spread of infections, with most cases concentrated in the north of the country (Remuzzi and52    Remuzzi, 2020). The distribution of positive cases from February 24 th to April 6 th , is summarized in 1A with a scale between 50 and 5000 cases (Figure1A): these values have been exceeded in 54 some areas of Lombardy and Piedmont, e.g. 11230 at Milan, 9712 at Bergamo, 9340 at Brescia, 55 5985 at Turin (data re-elaborated from the official daily reports of the Department of Civil 56 Protection, ICPD, 2020). Also, the relative percentage distribution of the positive test rate (Figure 57 1B) clearly exhibit higher values in Northern Italy despite a certain uncertainty of data due to the 58 different numbers and frequency of oropharyngeal swabs performed in various regions to such geographical trend, it was initially assumed that restrictions decided by 63 government authorities after the first outbreak in Lombardy, had contained the effects of the 64 infection, preventing its rapid spread to the rest of the country. Some authors, however, from the 65 clinical course of a large cohort of patients, have concluded that the epidemic coronavirus had been 66 circulating in Italy for several weeks before the first recognized outbreak (Cerada et al., 2020). In 67 this respect, the differentiated occurrence of infection cannot be fully explained by the containment 68 actions; also, the elevated mortality rate in Northern Italy suggests that other factors are involved 69 in the diffusion of infection and mortality rates. 70 Since the presence of comorbidities appeared determinant for the aetiology and severity of 71 the COVID-19 symptoms (Chen et al., 2020; Wang T. et al., 2020; Wu et al., 2020), the role of 72 atmospheric pollution in contributing to the high levels of SARS-CoV-2 lethality in Northern Italy has 73 been hypothesized (Conticini et al., 2020). The adverse effects of air pollutants on human health are 74 widely recognized in scientific literature, depending on various susceptibility factors such as age, 75 nutritional status and predisposing conditions (Kampa and Castanas, 2008). Chronic exposure to the 76 atmospheric pollution contributes to increased hospitalizations and mortality, primarily affecting 77 cardiovascular and respiratory systems, causing various diseases and pathologies including cancer 78 (Brunekreef and Holgate, 2002; Kampa and Castanas, 2008). Among air pollutants, the current focus 79 is mainly given on nitrogen dioxide (NO2), particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10) and ozone (O3), 80 frequently occurring at elevated concentrations in large areas of the planet.81

FIGREF1.text: we are providing additional evidence on the possible influence of air quality on the 87 spread of SARS-CoV-2 in Italian regions. Since the effects of air pollutants on human health not only 88 depend on their concentrations but also, if not especially, on chronicity of exposure, we have 89 elaborated the last four years (from 2016 to 2019, EEA, 2020) of regional distribution of NO2, PM2.-term condition of population exposure is also revealed by the number of days per 94 year in which the regulatory limits of O3 and PM10 are exceeded (Figure 3A-B): the critical situation 95 of Northern Italy is reflected by values of up to 80 days of exceedance per year (average of the last 96 three years, EAA, 2019). Worthy to remind, ozone is one of the main precursors for the formation 97 of NO2, and chronic exposure to this contaminant for almost a quarter of a year is undoubtedly of 98 primary importance. The chronic air pollution in Northern Italy is further represented by the number 99 of years during the last decade (2010-2019) in which the limit value for PM10 (50 µg/m 3 per day) has 100 been exceeded for at least 35 days (Figure 3C). Once again, these data confirm that the whole 101 Northern area below the Alpine arc has been constantly affected by significantly higher levels that atmospheric pollution may influence the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak in Italy 104 was also tested from the relationships between the confirmed cases of Covid-19 in up to 71 Italian 105 provinces (updated 6 April) with the corresponding air quality data. The latter were expressed as 106 average concentrations in the last 4 years of NO2, PM2.5 and PM10 (Figure 4A-C) and the number of 107 days exceeding the regulatory limits (averages of the last 3 years) for O3 and PM10 (Figure 4D-E). The 108 always significant correlations provided further evidence on the role that chronic exposure to 109 atmospheric contamination may have as a favourable context for the spread and virulence of the 110 SARS-CoV-2 within a population subjected to a higher incidence of respiratory and well known that exposure to atmospheric contaminants modulate the host's 113 inflammatory response leading to an overexpression of inflammatory cytokines and chemokines 114 (Gouda et al., 2018). Clear effects of Milan winter PM2.5 were observed on elevated production of 115 interleukin IL-6 and IL-8 in human bronchial cells (Longhin et al., 2018), and also NO2 was shown to 116 correlate with IL-6 levels on inflammatory status (Perret eta al., 2017). The impairment of 117 respiratory system and chronic disease by air pollution can thus facilitate viral infection in lower 118 tracts (Shinya et al., 2006; van Riel et al., 2006). 119 In addition, various studies have reported a direct relationship between the spread and 120 contagion capacity of some viruses with the atmospheric levels and mobility of air of the measles virus in China (Chen et al., 2017; Peng et al., 2020). 126 These evidences and presented elaborations would confirm that the anomalous variability 127 of the diffusion and virulence of SARS-CoV-2 in Italy could partly depend on the levels of 128 atmospheric contamination. Although the capability of this coronavirus to bind particulate matters 129 remains to be established, chronic exposure to atmospheric contamination and related diseases 130 may represent a risk factor in determining the severity of COVID-19 syndrome and the high 131 incidence of fatal events (Chen et al., 2020; Conticini et al., 2020; Wang D. et al., 2020; Wu et al., the actual pandemic event is demonstrating that infectious diseases represent 134 one of the key challenges for human society. Since periodic emergence of viral agents show an 135 increasing correlation with socio-economic, environmental and ecological factors (Morens et al., 136 2004; Jones et al., 2008), adequate programs for controlling and reducing atmospheric and 137 environmental pollution should be considered as part of an integrated approach for sustainable 138 development, human health protection and prevention of epidemic spreads. 139 140 Note: A complete description of the origin of the used data and the methods of graphic and statistical 141 processing is included in the Supplementary Materials.

FIGREF2.text: V., Brownstein, J. S., … Kraemer, M. U. G. (2020). Epidemiological data from the COVID-19 outbreak, real-time case information. Scientific Data, 7(1). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-020-0448-0 Regional distribution of COVID-19 outbreak in Italy (from 24 February to 6 April 2020: A) Abundance of COVID-19 cases (absolute number), chromatic scale between 50 and 5000; B) Percentage rate of positive subjects referred to the number of performed tests (oropharyngeal swabs); C) Percentage of reported mortality rate. Data obtained and re-elaborated from the official daily reports of Italian Civil Protection Department (ICPD, 2020).

FIGREF3.text: Regional data on air quality levels: A) nitrogen dioxide (NO2); B) particulate matter of 2.5 µm or less (PM2.5); C) particulate matter of 2.5-10 µm (PM10). Data are referred to the means of values of last four years (2016-2019), expressed as µg/m 3 (obtained and elaborated from the European Environmental Agency, accessed on 6 April, EEA, 2020).

FIGREF4.text: Number of days per year exceeding the regulatory limits relating to A) ozone (O3) and to B) particulate matter (PM10), as average means of the last 3 years (2017-2019); C) number of years in which the PM10 limit was exceeded for at least 35 days per year, from 2010 to 2019. Data are obtained and elaborated from annual reports (Legambiente, 2018; 2019; 2020) and referred to the official statistics of the European Environmental Agency (EEA, 2019).

FIGREF5.text: Statistical correlation between the regional distribution of COVID-19 cases and the air qualityparameters in Italy: incidence of COVID-19 cases vs levels of A) NO2, B) PM2.5 and C) PM10 (four years means); incidence of COVID-19 cases vs number of days exceeding regulatory limits of D) O3 and E) PM10 (three years means). Data obtained and elaborated from EEA (2019; 2020), ICPD (2020), and Legambiente (2018; 2019; 2020).
